message_1: Prove that the formula (p ∧ q) → p is a tautology, where p and q are propositional variables.
message_2:
To prove that the formula (p ∧ q) → p is a tautology, we will use a truth table to show that the formula is true for all possible combinations of truth values for p and q.

A truth table is a table that shows all possible combinations of truth values for a given formula. In this case, we have two propositional variables, p and q, so there are 2^2 = 4 possible combinations of truth values.

Here is the truth table for (p ∧ q) → p:

| p | q | p ∧ q | (p ∧ q) → p |
|---|---|-------|-------------|
| T | T |   T   |      T      |
| T | F |   F   |      T      |
| F | T |   F   |      T      |
| F | F |   F   |      T      |

Explanation of the table:

1. When p is true and q is true, (p ∧ q) is true, and (p ∧ q) → p is true.
2. When p is true and q is false, (p ∧ q) is false, and (p ∧ q) → p is true (since a false statement implies a true statement).
3. When p is false and q is true, (p ∧ q) is false, and (p ∧ q) → p is true (since a false statement implies a false statement).
4. When p is false and q is false, (p ∧ q) is false, and (p ∧ q) → p is true (since a false statement implies a false statement).

Since the formula (p ∧ q) → p is true for all possible combinations of truth values for p and q, it is a tautology.
